Problem:
Consider a system where the function \\( z = x^2 + y^2 \\) models the energy states in a two-dimensional space depending on positions x and y. We explore the effect of a rotational transformation defined by \\( R(\\theta) = \\begin{bmatrix} \\cos(\\theta) & -\\sin(\\theta) \\\\ \\sin(\\theta) & \\cos(\\theta) \\end{bmatrix} \\) applied to a vector \\( v = \\begin{bmatrix} x \\\\ y \\end{bmatrix} \\).

Given an observed energy state \\( z \\), is it possible to determine whether the scaling transformation \\( S \\), the rotational transformation \\( R(\\theta) \\), or both were applied solely based on the value of \\( z \\)?
Explanation: Multiple combinations of scaling and rotation can result in the same energy state, due to the scalar nature of \\( z \\) which remains insensitive to rotational components. As not all transformations uniquely modify \\( z \\), distinguishing which were applied based on \\( z \\) alone is impossible.
